title: Dietary Protein Intake Above the Current RDA and Bone Health: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials

sections.abstract:
Dietary intake of protein is fundamental for optimal acquisition and maintenance of bone across all life
stages; however, it has been hypothesized that intakes above the current recommended dietary
allowance (RDA) might be beneﬁcial for bone health. We utilized the Preferred Reporting Items for
Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines when preparing and reporting this systematic
review and meta-analysis. A literature search strategy through April 11, 2017, was developed for the
following 3 databases: PubMed, Ovid Medline, and Agricola. Included studies were those randomized
controlled trials and prospective cohort studies among healthy adults ages 18 and older that examined
the relationships between varying doses of protein intake at or above the current U.S. RDA (0.8 g/kg/d or
10%–15% of total caloric intake) from any source on fracture, bone mineral density (BMD)/bone mineral
content (BMC), and/or markers of bone turnover. Twenty-nine articles were included for data extraction
(16 randomized controlled trials [RCTs] and 13 prospective cohort studies). Meta-analysis of the
prospective cohort studies showed high vs low protein intakes resulted in a statistically signiﬁcant 16%
decrease in hip fractures (standardized mean difference [SMD]D 0.84, 95% conﬁdence interval [CI], 0.73,
0.95; I
2 D 36.8%). Data from studies included in these analyses collectively lean toward the hypothesis that
protein intake above the current RDA is beneﬁcial to BMD at several sites. This systematic review supports
that protein intakes above the current RDA may have some beneﬁcial role in preventing hip fractures and
BMD loss. There were no differences between animal or plant proteins, although data in this area were
scarce. Larger, long-term, and more well-controlled clinical trials measuring fracture outcomes and BMD
are needed to adequately assess whether protein intake above the current RDA is bene ﬁcial as a
preventative measure and/or intervention strategy for osteoporosis.
Key teaching points:
/C15Bone health is a multifactorial musculoskeletal issue, and optimal protein intakes are key in developing
and maintaining bone throughout the life span.
/C15Dietary protein at levels above the current RDA may be beneﬁcial in preventing hip fractures and BMD
loss.
/C15Plant vs animal proteins do not seem to differ in their ability to prevent bone loss; however, data in this
area are scarce.
/C15Larger, long-term RCTs using women not using hormone replacement therapy (HRT) are needed to
adequately assess the magnitude of impact that protein intakes above the RDA have on preventing
bone loss.
Abbreviations: BMC, bone mineral content; BMD, bone mineral density; RDA, recommended dietary allowance; HRT,
hormone replacement therapy; EFSA, European Food Safety Authority; PRI, population reference intake; RCT, ran-
domized controlled trial; BAP, bone alkaline phosphatase; IGF-1, insulin-like growth factor-1; IGFBP-3, insulin-like
growth factor binding protein-3; NTX, N-telopeptide of type-1 collagen; NAE, net acid excretion; DPD, deoxypyridi-
noline; CTX, C-terminal telopeptide of type II collagen; P1NP, procollagen type I N-terminal propeptide; IOF, Interna-
tional Osteoporosis Foundation; IFCC, International Federation of Clinical Chemistry and Laboratory Medicine;
NBHA, National Bone Health Alliance
KEYWORDS
Protein; calcium; bone;
fractures; bone density
sections.introduction:
Protein makes up roughly 50% of bone volume and about one
third of its mass[1], and dietary intake of this essential nutrient
is fundamental for optimal acquisition and maintenance of
bone across all life stages. A variety of proteins, predominantly
collagen, make up the organic matrix of bone, which undergoes
continuous turnover and remodeling. Although considerable
attention has been given to the type and amount of dietary pro-
tein intake necessary to achieve optimal bone health,
CONTACT Taylor C. Wallace, PhD, CFS, FACN taylor.wallace@me.com Department of Nutrition and Food Studies, George Mason University, 10340 Democracy
Lane, Suite 306, Fairfax, VA 22030.
© Taylor C. Wallace, and Cara L. Frankenfeld
This is an Open Access article. Non-commercial re-use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly attributed, cited, and is not altered, transformed, or
built upon in any way, is permitted. The moral rights of the named author(s) have been asserted.
JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN COLLEGE OF NUTRITION
2017, VOL. 36, NO. 6, 481– 496
https://doi.org/10.1080/07315724.2017.1322924

authoritative bodies have varying recommendations around the
intake of dietary protein, largely established on non-bone
health outcomes. In 2015, the European Safety Authority estab-
lished a population reference intake of 0.83 g/kg/d for adult
men and women of all ages[2]. Dietary reference intakes for
protein in the United States and Canada have not been updated
since 2005[3].
There are many nutrients and lifestyle factors that inﬂuence
bone health; however, intake of dietary protein, particularly
animal-derived proteins, has been hypothesized to be both det-
rimental and beneﬁcial to bone. Since 1920, higher dietary pro-
tein intakes have consistently been shown to increase urinary
calcium [4,5]. Early metabolic balance studies reported that
higher protein intakes did not affect intestinal calcium absorp-
tion [6–13], suggesting that the additional urinary calcium
must be derived from bone tissue. It has been proposed that the
body compensates for the systemic metabolic acid load of sul-
fur-containing amino acids predominantly present in animal-
derived proteins by releasing alkali stores in bone (e.g., calcium
salts). However, contrary to the early metabolic balance studies,
contemporary dual stable calcium isotope studies have found
higher protein intakes to increase intestinal calcium absorption,
such that the increase in urinary calcium can be accounted for
by the improved absorption efﬁciency [14–16]. Factors that
inﬂuence muscle anabolism, including protein intake, also
affect bone mass; bone health is a multifactorial musculoskele-
tal issue, and protein intake for bone health has been hypothe-
sized to be higher than current recommended intakes,
particularly in the elderly[1]. Cross-linking of collagen mole-
cules in bone involves posttranslational modiﬁcations of amino
acids (e.g., hydroxylation of lysine and proline) and thus many
of the collagen fragments released during bone resorption can-
not be reutilized during bone formation[1].
Three published meta-analyses have attempted to address
the longstanding scientiﬁc controversy surrounding the effec-
tiveness of protein intake on bone health; however, none have
looked speciﬁcally at intakes above the recommended dietary
intake (RDA). Darling et al. found no effect of protein intake
on fracture outcomes[17], whereas a more recent meta-analy-
sis by Wu et al. found a slight reduction in hip fractures[18]
when comparing high vs low protein intakes. The most com-
prehensive meta-analysis to date by Shams-White et al. found
positive associations for the relationship of high vs low protein
intakes and bone mineral density (BMD)/bone mineral content
(BMC) for nearly all bone sites; however, statistical signiﬁcance
was only present at the lumbar spine[19].
The peer-reviewed literature is clearly limited by heteroge-
neity and a variety of designs, doses, durations, and outcomes
across studies. Prior systematic reviews and meta-analyses are
further limited by many included studies in which other life-
style factors may counter and/or mask the effects of increased
protein intake on bone. These systematic reviews and meta-
analyses [17–19] include many weight loss studies and/or trials
of postmenopausal women who use hormone replacement
therapy (HRT); both are strong drivers of bone turnover and
likely inﬂuence bone to a much greater extent than the protein
intervention. By restricting to studies that do not include
weight loss or women using HRT, this systematic review was
designed to speciﬁcally examine whether an independent rela-
tionship exists between dietary protein intake above the current
RDA of 0.8 g/kg/d on fractures, BMD/BMC, and markers of
bone turnover.
sections.methods:
The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and
Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement is followed in reporting
this systematic review and meta-analysis[20].
Data sources and searches
A search strategy was developed in consultation with 2 librar-
ians ﬁrst using nomenclatures for Ovid Medline and then
adjusted for other electronic databases. The searches were
implemented through April 11, 2017, in 3 databases: PubMed,
Ovid Medline, and Agricola. The searches were limited to the
English language and human studies that examined the rela-
tionships of protein intake (food or supplemental sources) on
bone health outcomes. The complete search strategies are pre-
sented inTable 1.
Study eligibility criteria
We included all randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and pro-
spective cohort studies among healthy adults ages 18 and older
that examined the relationships between varying doses of

protein intake at or above the current U.S. RDA (0.8 g/kg/d or
10%–15% of total caloric intake) from any source on fracture,
BMD/BMC, and/or markers of bone turnover. Included bone
outcomes of interest are presented inTable 2. Adults who were
“healthy obese”; those with past or current fractures but no
other preexisting conditions; and older adults with sarcopenia
or frailty but no other clear disease (e.g., excluded populations
with renal disease) were included in the deﬁnition of healthy
adults.
Exclusion criteria are as follows:
/C15Studies among children and adolescents less than 18 years
of age and those that only looked at bone development
before peak bone mass.
/C15Studies of pregnant or lactating women.
/C15Studies of vegan individuals (vegetarian studies were
acceptable).
/C15Studies that exclusively enrolled subjects with diagnosed
disease (e.g., cardiovascular disease).
/C15Studies where more than 20% of the baseline population
was diagnosed with a disease.
/C15Studies designed to examine outcomes in response to pro-
tein type but not protein quantity (i.e., protein source
comparison only).
/C15Studies supplementing protein in the form of full isoﬂa-
vone soy (i.e., isoﬂavones not removed or minimized).
/C15Acute feeding studies of 24 hours or less.
/C15Studies of bone health in women where oral contraceptive
use or HRT is not excluded, not stratiﬁed if allowed, or
not controlled for in analysis if allowed.
/C15Protein intake more than 35% of calories or 2.5 g/kg and
no study arm with a lower intake value.
/C15Protein intake less than 0.66 g/kg/d.
/C15Studies designed for weight loss or conducted in a manner
where subjects did not maintain energy balance.
/C15Protein provided as a puriﬁed amino acid bolus or admin-
istered intravenously.
/C15Concomitant intervention with drugs or supplements that
inﬂuence body weight.
/C15Letters, abstracts, case reports, case series, position state-
ments, hypotheses, study designs, conference proceed-
ings, prevalence surveys.
/C15Studies published in a language other than English.
/C15Cross-sectional, case –control, animal, and/or in vitro
studies.
Study selection process
Citations were imported into Mendeley free reference manager
and PDF organizer (Elsevier, Amsterdamn, The Netherlands).
All duplicates across the 3 literature searches were removed. For
citations identiﬁed from the 3 databases, titles wereﬁrst screened
by 2 investigators to exclude cross-sectional, animal, andin vitro
studies, as well as review articles. All abstracts identiﬁed in the lit-
erature searches were then independently screened by 2 investi-
gators. For all abstracts that were deemed relevant by 2 screeners,
full-text articles were retrieved and independently screened by 2
investigators based on the ﬁnal study eligibility criteria. All
abstract and full-text screening conﬂicts were resolved through
sections.discussion:
between the 2 investigators and aﬁ
nal decision was
reached by the consensus of the entire research team.
Data extraction
A data extraction sheet was created in Excel to capture all data
of interest from RCTs and observational studies. One indepen-
dent extractor completed data extraction for all studies, which
was validated by a second investigator. Any disagreements
were discussed among the investigators and resolved via con-
sensus. The items extracted included (1) study identiﬁcation
details (including studyﬁrst author; year of study publication;
cohort name; title of publication [ﬁrst 5 words]; country where
study was conducted; region of country where study was con-
ducted; double-blind [yes or no]); (2) subject baseline demo-
graphics; (3) intervention details (including protein source;
level of protein intake at baseline and incremental supplemen-
tation; duration of supplementation [days]); (4) dietary details
(including baseline diet assessment method, baseline diet infor-
mation); (5) data details (including number of completed sub-
jects in each group; number of enrolled subjects); (6) outcome
assessment method; (7) outcome unit as reported by author;
(8) standard deviations (recorded if reported by author or cal-
culated from available data); and (9) pre- and poststudy out-
come means.
Protein intake
Data were taken directly as reported by the author where possi-
ble or calculated from data provided by the authors in the
publication.
Data synthesis
All included studies were summarized in narrative form and
are presented in Tables 3 and 4. The items presented in the
tables included (1) study identiﬁcation details (including study
ﬁrst author; year of study publication; cohort name); (2) partic-
ipant characteristics; (3) baseline age or age range; (4) exposure
assessment; (5) follow-up period; and (6) outcomes. Summary
tables were organized by study type;
sections.results:
were quantitatively
and qualitatively summarized by outcome of interest.
Meta-analysis
Clinical trials reporting urinary calcium and urinary N-termi-
nal telopeptide (NTX) outcomes were included. Other outcome
measures that were evaluated in some studies had too few stud-
ies to evaluate (<4 studies) included calcium absorption, cal-
cium balance, calcium retention, fecal calcium, plasma or
serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), serum insulin-like
growth factor binding protein-3 (IGFBP-3), and serum osteo-
calcin. Serum bone alkaline phosphatase (n D 5 studies) and

serum calcium (n D 8 studies) had more studies but are not
believed to be sufﬁciently robust measures of bone turnover
[134] and were not included in the meta-analyses. BMC and
BMD were not evaluated because the length of the intervention
trials was not suf ﬁciently long enough to see appreciable
changes in BMC or BMD. Prospective observational (cohort)
studies reporting fracture or hip fracture were included. There
were 7 unique studies with information about fracture
outcomes.
Prior to analysis, standard deviations were calculated from
standard errors for studies in which standard errors were
reported. For crossover trials where a pooled standard devia-
tion or standard error was not reported, separate values pro-
vided for the experimental and control periods were used. As
noted by Cochrane, this will introduce some bias toward more
conservative results. Standardized mean differences and stan-
dard deviations were calculated for each study. Analyses were
conducted using Stata 14 (Stata Corp., College Station, TX).
Results
The search yielded 2433 citations including 140 duplicates that
were automatically removed. Three additional articles [131–
133] were identiﬁed by searching the reference lists of articles
of the other studies included in the analyses, as well as the 3
previous meta-analyses[17–19], which did not speciﬁcally look
at protein intakes above the RDA. Two thousand two hundred
and ninety-six articles were identiﬁed for dual abstract screen-
ing, of which 115 were identiﬁed for full-text screening[21–
135]. Overall, 31 articles were included for data extraction (16
RCTs and 15 prospective cohort studies;Figure 1; Tables 3–4)
[23,28,30,41,50,53,59,67,69,71,73–76,79,83,91,94,97,98,102,106,
108,120,129,130–135].
Heterogeneity was not signiﬁcantly present for urinary cal-
cium (I
2 D 28.3%, heterogeneity chi-squared p D 0.167) and
hip fracture (I2 D 49.6%, p D 0.114), and aﬁxed effects models
was used. Heterogeneity was signiﬁcantly present for urinary
NTX (I2 D 66.3%, heterogeneity chi-squaredp D 0.007), and a
random effects model was used. Inverse weighting was used to
obtain the pooled standardized mean difference (SMD) and
corresponding 95% conﬁdence intervals (Cis). For fractures,
pooled relative risk for the association between the highest cate-
gory vs lowest category of protein intake was calculated. Het-
erogeneity was signiﬁcantly present (I
2 D 87.3%, heterogeneity
chi-squared p < 0.001), and a random effects model was used.
There were too few studies to conduct stratiﬁed analyses for
study design characteristics.
Observational studies
Total fractures
Beasley et al. [30] found that postmenopausal women in the
Women’s Health Initiative (WHI) who consumed 20% higher
calibrated protein intake did not show any statistically
Figure 1. PRISMA ﬂow diagram.
486 T. C. WALLACE AND C. L. FRANKENFELD

signiﬁcant decrease in the risk of total fractures after 6 years of
follow-up. Langsetmo et al. [83] divided total fractures into
main and fragility fractures. They found no statistically signiﬁ-
cant effects of protein in the highest vs lowest categories of
exposure on incident main fractures or incident fragility frac-
tures in men and postmenopausal women after 9.5–9.7 years of
follow-up. Langsetmo et al. [135] divided total fractures into
major osteoporotic fractures and low-trauma fractures. They
found higher protein intake to be signiﬁcantly associated with a
decreased risk of both major osteoporotic fractures and low-
trauma fractures in older men after 15 years of follow-up.
Spine fractures
Beasley et al. [30] found that postmenopausal women in the
WHI who consumed 20% higher calibrated protein intake did
not show any statistically signiﬁcant decrease in the risk of
spine fractures after 6 years of follow-up. Langsetmo et al.
[135] found that older men who consumed higher protein
intakes from any source (i.e., total, dairy, nondairy animal pro-
tein, or plant protein) did not show any statistically signiﬁcant
effects on the risk of spine fractures after 15 years of follow-up.
Forearm fractures
Beasley et al. [30] found that postmenopausal women in the
WHI who consumed 20% higher calibrated protein intake
showed a statistically signiﬁcant decrease in the risk of forearm
fractures after 6 years of follow-up.
Hip fracture
Six studies assessed the effect of protein intake and hip frac-
tures [30,94,97,98,134,135]. Munger et al.[97] found a statisti-
cally signiﬁcant reduced risk of hip fractures in the highest vs
lowest categories of both total protein and animal protein
intakes in postmenopausal women after 1–3 years of follow-up.
Beasley et al. [30] found that postmenopausal women in the
WHI who consumed 20% higher calibrated protein intake did
not show any statistically signiﬁcant decrease in the risk of hip
fractures after 6 years of follow-up. Langsetmo et al. [135]
found that among older men who consumed higher total pro-
tein intakes, including those from dairy and nondairy animal
proteins (but not plant proteins), there was a signiﬁcant reduc-
tion in the risk of hip fractures after 15 years of follow-up.
Fung et al.[134] found signiﬁcant inverse associations for each
10 g increase in total protein and animal protein intakes in
men but not in postmenopausal women. Both plant and dairy
proteins (but not total and animal proteins) were associated
with a signiﬁcantly lower risk of hip fracture when results for
men and women were combined. Misra et al.[94] found no sta-
tistically signiﬁcant effects in the highest vs lowest categories of
exposure among elderly men and postmenopausal women after
a median 11.6 years of follow-up. Mussolino et al.[98] also
found no statistically signiﬁcant effects in the highest vs lowest
categories of exposure in men after 22 years of follow-up.
Meta-analysis of the prospective cohort studies showed
that high vs low protein intakes resulted in a statistically signiﬁ-
cant decrease in hip fractures (SMDD 0.84, 95% CI, 0.73, 0.95,
I
2 D 36.8%; Figure 2).
BMC
Meng et al. [91] found statistically signiﬁcant improvements
between the highest vs lowest category of exposure for total
body and appendicular BMC in postmenopausal elderly
women after 5 years of follow-up.
BMD— Cortical bone
Pedone et al. [132] showed that high vs low protein intakes
resulted in statistically signiﬁcant differences in cortical BMD
in postmenopausal women after 6 years of follow-up.
BMD— Trabecular bone
Two studies assessed the effect of protein intake on trabecular
bone BMD[108,132]. Sahni et al.[108] did notﬁnd any statisti-
cally signiﬁcant effects on trabecular bone BMD in men and
women age 26–86 years after a mean 4.6 years of follow-up;

Pedone et al.[132] also did notﬁnd any statistically signiﬁcant
effects in postmenopausal women after 6 years of follow-up.
BMD— Femoral neck
Five studies assessed the effect of protein intake on femoral
neck BMD[53,59,108,120,131]. Devine et al.[53] found statis-
tically signiﬁcant improvements in the highest vs lowest catego-
ries of exposure in postmenopausal women after 1 year of
follow-up, as did Hannan et al.[59] after 4 years of follow-up.
Hannan et al.[59] also found that lower animal protein intakes
produced statistically signiﬁcant greater losses in BMD at the
femoral neck. Tucker et al.[120] also found statistically signiﬁ-
cant improvements in the highest vs lowest categories of expo-
sure in older men and postmenopausal women after 4 years of
follow-up. Ho-Pham et al. [131] found no difference in loss
between omnivorous and vegan women (menopausal status
unclear) after 2 years of follow-up; Sahni et al.[108] also did
not ﬁnd any difference in loss in men and women age 26–
86 years after a mean 4.6 years of follow-up.
BMD— Hip and total hip
Three studies assessed the effect of protein intake on BMD at
the hip[30,53]. Beasley et al.[30] found that each 20% increase
in calibrated protein intake was associated with a statistically
signiﬁcant increase in BMD in the WHI trial of postmeno-
pausal women after 6 years of follow-up. Devine et al.[53] also
found statistically signiﬁcant increases in highest vs lowest pro-
tein categories of exposure[53]. Langsetmo et al.[135] found
that the association between protein and fracture varied by pro-
tein source. Increased dairy protein and nondairy animal pro-
tein intakes were associated with a decreased risk of hip
fracture (hazard ratio [HR]D 0.80, 95% CI, 0.65–0.98; HR D
0.84, 95% CI, 0.72–0.97, respectively), whereas plant source
protein was not (HRD 0.99, 95% CI, 0.78–1.24) among older
men after 15 years of follow-up.
BMD— Intertrochanter and trochancher
Devine et al.[53] assessed the effect of protein intake on BMD
at the intertrochanter region of the hip and found statistically
signiﬁcant improvements in the highest vs lowest categories of
exposure in postmenopausal women over the age of 70 years.
Four studies assessed the effect of protein intake on BMD at
the trochanter region of the hip[53,59,108,120]. Devine et al.
[53] found statistically signiﬁ
cant improvements in the highest
vs lowest categories of exposure in postmenopausal women
over the age of 70 years after 1 year of follow-up, as did Tucker
et al. [120] in older men and postmenopausal women after
4 years of follow-up. Sahni et al.[108] showed statistically sig-
niﬁcant loss in men but not in women age 26–86 years after a
mean 4.6 years follow-up period [108]. Hannan et al. [59]
found no statistically signiﬁcant effects in the highest vs lowest
categories of exposure in elderly men and postmenopausal
women after 4 years of follow-up.
BMD— Lumbar spine and spine
Three studies assessed the effect of protein intake on BMD at
the lumbar spine[59,108,120]. Hannan et al.[59] and Tucker
et al.[120] found a statistically signiﬁcant improvement in the
highest vs lowest categories of exposure in elderly men and
postmenopausal women after 4 years of follow-up. Hannan
et al. [59] also found that lower animal protein intakes pro-
duced statistically signiﬁcant greater losses in BMD at the
spine. Sahni et al.[108] did notﬁnd any statistically signiﬁcant
effects in men or women age 26–86 years after a mean 4.6 years
of follow-up.
Two studies assessed the effect of protein intake on BMD at
the spine[30,106]. Beasley et al.[30] did notﬁnd a statistically
signiﬁcant association between protein intake and spine BMD
in the WHI study of postmenopausal women after 6 years of
follow-up, nor did Rapuri et al.[106] in a small study of healthy
ambulatory women after 3 years of follow-up.
BMD— Proximal femur
Rapuri et al.[106] assessed the effect of protein intake on BMD
at the proximal femur but found no statistically signiﬁcant
improvements in a small study of healthy ambulatory women
after 3 years of follow-up.
BMD— Radial shaft, radial midshaft, and radius
Tucker et al.[120] found statistically signiﬁcant improvements
in BMD at the radial shaft in the highest vs lowest categories of
exposure in older men and postmenopausal women after
4 years of follow-up. Rapuri et al.[106] assessed the effect of
protein intake on BMD at the radial mid-shaft but found no
statistically signi ﬁcant improvements in a small study of
healthy ambulatory women after 3 years of follow-up. Hannan
et al. [59] assessed the effect of protein intake on BMD at the
radius but found no statistically signiﬁcant improvements in
older men and postmenopausal women after 4 years of follow-
up. Hannan et al. [59] also found no statistically signiﬁcant
effects of lower animal protein intakes on BMD at the radius.
BMD— Total body
Two studies assessed the effect of protein intake on total body
BMD [30,106]. Beasley et al.[30] found that each 20% increase
in calibrated protein intake was associated with a statistically
signiﬁcant increase in total body BMD in the WHI trial of post-
menopausal women after 6 years of follow-up, contrary to
Rapuri et al.[106], who did notﬁnd any statistically signiﬁcant
improvements in a small study of healthy ambulatory women
after 3 years of follow-up.
BMD— Ward’s area
Two studies assessed the effect of protein intake and BMD at
the Ward’sa r e a[59,120]. Hannan et al.[59] and Tucker et al.
[120] found statistically signiﬁcant improvements in the high-
est vs lowest categories of exposure in older men and postmen-
opausal women after 4 years of follow-up.
Serum and urinary biomarkers
Rapuri et al.[106] found statistically signiﬁcant increases in cal-
cium absorption in the highest vs lowest categories of exposure
in postmenopausal women after 1 year of follow-up and
observed a statistically signiﬁcant decrease in serum alkaline
phosphatase in the highest vs lowest categories of exposure
among healthy ambulatory women after 3 years of follow-up.
They observed no statistically signiﬁcant effects on serum cal-
cium, urinary calcium, serum osteocalcin, or urinary NTX in

the highest vs lowest categories of exposure among healthy
ambulatory women after 3 years of follow-up.
Other outcomes
Other outcomes evaluated in one study included broadband
ultrasound attenuation, speed of sound, and stiffness. Devine
et al.[53] found statistically signiﬁcant improvements in broad-
band ultrasound attenuation at the calcaneus of the left foot
and stiffness in the highest vs lowest categories of exposure in
postmenopausal women after 1 year of follow-up. They
observed no statistically signiﬁcant effects of protein on speed
of sound in the highest vs lowest categories of exposure among
postmenopausal women after 1 year of follow-up.
Clinical studies
BMC
Ballard et al. [28] found no statistically signiﬁcant effects on
arm, leg, and whole-body BMC in young males and females
age 18–25 years with protein supplementation at 275% of the
RDA after a 26-week intervention period.
BMD— Distal radius and ulna
Zou et al. [130] found statistically signiﬁcant improvements
with protein supplementation at 171% of the RDA in distal
radius and ulna BMD in young females with a mean age of
19.6 years after a 35-week intervention period.
BMD— Femoral neck, femoral neck bucking ratio, femoral
neck cross section area, and femoral neck cross-sectional
moment of inertia (CSMI)
Two studies assessed the effect of increased protein on femoral
neck BMD[76,129]. Zhu et al.[129] found statistically signiﬁ-
cant improvements with protein supplementation at 150% of
the RDA in femoral neck BMD but not in femoral neck buck-
ing ratio, femoral neck cross section area, or femoral neck polar
CSMI in postmenopausal women after a 104-week intervention
period. Kerstetter et al. [76] found no statistically signiﬁcant
effects with protein supplementation at 163% of the RDA on
femoral neck BMD in older men and postmenopausal women
after a 78-week intervention period.
BMD— Lumbar spine
Three studies assessed the effect of increased protein on lumbar
spine BMD[23,76,130]. Aoe et al.[23] found statistically signif-
icant improvements in women (menopausal status mixed) with
protein supplementation at 163% of the RDA after a 26-week
intervention period. Kerstetter et al.[76] did notﬁnd any statis-
tically signiﬁcant effect in older men and postmenopausal
women with protein supplementation at 163% of the RDA after
a 30-week intervention period, nor did Zou et al.[130] in pre-
menopausal women with protein supplementation at 171% of
the RDA after a 35-week intervention period.
BMD— Tibia and total tibia
Ballard et al.[28] found no statistically signiﬁcant effect with
protein supplementation at 275% of the RDA on tibia or total
tibia BMD in young males and females age 18–25 years after a
26-week intervention period.
BMD— Total body
Zou et al.[130] found no statistically signiﬁcant effect with pro-
tein supplementation at 171% of the RDA on total body BMD
in postmenopausal females after a 35-week intervention period.
BMD— Total hip
Two studies assessed the effect of increased protein on total hip
BMD [76,129]. Zhu et al.
[129] found no statistically signiﬁcant
effect in older men and postmenopausal women with protein
supplementation at 150% of the RDA after a 78-week interven-
tion period. Kerstetter et al.[76] found statistically signiﬁcant
increases in older men and postmenopausal women with pro-
tein supplementation at 163% of the RDA after a 78-week
intervention period.
Calcium absorption
Three studies assessed the effect of increased protein on cal-
cium absorption[41,74,79]. Cao et al.[41] found no statistically
signiﬁcant effects in postmenopausal women with protein sup-
plementation at 213% of the RDA after a 7-week intervention
period, nor did Kerstetter et al.[74] in premenopausal women
age 21–39 years with protein supplementation at 263% of the
RDA after a 0.71-week intervention period or in a mixed popu-
lation of premenopausal and postmenopausal women with pro-
tein supplementation at 263% of the RDA after a 0.6-week
intervention period[79]. Kerstetter et al.[74] also found no sta-
tistically signiﬁcant effects between meat and soy protein dur-
ing the intervention.
Calcium balance
Three studies assessed the effect of increased protein on
calcium balance [41,67,102]. Cao et al.[41] found statistically
signiﬁcant improvements in postmenopausal women with pro-
tein supplementation at 213% of the RDA after a 7-week inter-
vention period. In contrast, Hunt et al. [67] found no
statistically signiﬁcant effects in postmenopausal women with
protein supplementation at 200% of the RDA after a 7-week
intervention period. Pannemans et al.[102] found statistically
signiﬁcant improvements in older men and postmenopausal
women but no statistically signiﬁcant effects in younger men
and women after a 3-week intervention period (not able to
calculate percentage above RDA).
Fecal calcium
Three studies assessed the effect of increased protein on fecal
calcium [67,71,102]. Hunt et al.[67] found no statistically sig-
niﬁcant effects among postmenopausal women with protein
supplementation at 200% of the RDA after a 7-week interven-
tion period. Likewise, Jenkins et al.[71] found no statistically
signiﬁcant effects in men and postmenopausal women with
protein supplementation at 311% of the RDA after a 4.3-week
intervention period. Pannemans et al.[102] found a statistically
signiﬁcant improvement in young men and women with a
mean age of 29.3 years but no statistically signiﬁcant effects in
older men and postmenopausal women after a 3-week inter-
vention period (not able to calculate percentage above RDA).

Urinary calcium
Twelve studies assessed the effect of increased protein on uri-
nary calcium [41,50,67,69,71,74–76,79,102,129,133]. Seven
studies found statistically signiﬁcant increases in urinary cal-
cium in men, premenopausal women, and postmenopausal
women with protein supplementation above the RDA after
intervention periods of 0.6 week and 7 weeks
[41,67,69,71,74,79,133]. Four studies found no statistically sig-
niﬁcant effects on urinary calcium in men, premenopausal

tation above the RDA after an intervention period between 0.6
and 104 weeks[50,75,76,129]. Pannemans et al.[102] found a
statistically signiﬁcant increase in older men and postmeno-
pausal women but not in young men and women with a mean
age of 29.3 years after a 3-week intervention period (not able to
calculate percentage above RDA). Meta-analysis of RCTs
showed that high vs low protein intakes signiﬁcantly increase
in urinary calcium excretion (SMDD 0.48, 95% CI, 0.30, 0.66,

Urinary net acid excretion
Kerstetter et al. [79] found statistically signiﬁcant improve-
ments in net acid excretion in a mixed population of premeno-
pausal and postmenopausal women with protein

Urinary N-terminal telopeptide
Eight studies assessed the effect of increased protein on urinary
NTX [23,28,41,50,69,71,73,79]. Six studies found statistically
signiﬁcant improvements in urinary NTX in men, premeno-
pausal women, and postmenopausal women with protein
supplementation between 148% and 311% of the RDA after
intervention periods between 0.6 and 26 weeks
[23,28,50,69,71,79]. Two studies found no statistically signiﬁ-
cant effects on urinary NTX in premenopausal and postmeno-
pausal women with protein supplementation between 213%
and 263% of the RDA after an intervention period between 0.6
and 7 weeks [41,73]. Meta-analysis of the RCTs showed that
high vs low protein intakes did not signiﬁcantly affect urinary
NTX (SMDD¡ 018, 95% CI,¡0.99, 0.26,I
2 D 66.3%; Figure 4).
Kerstetter et al.[79] also found no statistically signiﬁcant effects
between meat and soy protein during the 0.6-week intervention
period.
Urinary deoxypyridinoline
Cao et al.[41] found no statistically signiﬁcant effects with pro-
tein supplementation at 213% of the RDA in urinary DPD
among postmenopausal women after a 7-week intervention
period.
Serum bone alkaline phosphatase
Five studies assessed the effect of increased protein on serum
bone alkaline phosphatase [28,67,71,73,130]. None of the 5
studies found statistically signiﬁcant effects in serum alkaline
phosphatase in younger men and women, older men, and post-
menopausal women with protein supplementation between
171% and 311% the RDA after intervention periods between
0.6 and 35 weeks[28,67,71,73,130].
Serum calcium
Seven studies assessed the effect of increased protein intake on
serum calcium [41,50,71,74,75,79,133]. None of the 7 studies
found statistically signiﬁcant effects on serum calcium in youn-
ger men and women, older men, and postmenopausal women
with protein supplementation between 125% and 311% of the
RDA after intervention periods between 0.6 and 9 weeks
[41,50,71,74,75,79,133].

Serum insulin-like growth factor-1 and plasma IGF-1
Four studies assessed the effect of increased protein on serum
IGF-1 [41,50,76,129]. All 4 studies found statistically signiﬁcant
improvements in serum IGF-1 in older men and postmeno-
pausal women with protein supplementation between 148%
and 213% the RDA after an intervention period between 7 and
104 weeks[41,50,76,129].
Ballard et al. [28] found borderline statistically signiﬁcant

age 18–25 years with protein supplementation at 275% of the
RDA after a 26-week intervention[28].
Serum insulin-like growth factor binding protein-3
Ballard et al.[28] did notﬁnd any statistically signiﬁcant effects
on serum IGFBP-3 among young men and women age 18–
25 years with protein supplementation at 275% of the RDA
after a 26-week intervention[28].
Serum NTX
Zou et al.[130] did not ﬁnd any statistically signiﬁcant effects
on serum NTX among young women with a mean age of
19.6 years with protein supplementation at 171% of the RDA
after a 35-week intervention[130].
Serum osteocalcin
Five studies assessed the effect of increased protein on serum
osteocalcin [23,41,50,73,79]. None of the 5 studies found statis-
tically signiﬁcant effects on serum osteocalcin in premeno-
pausal women, postmenopausal women, or older men with
protein supplementation between 148% and 263% of the RDA
after an intervention period between 0.6 and 78 weeks
[23,41,50,73,79].
Serum collagen type 1 cross-linked C-telopeptide and
procollagen type 1 N-terminal propeptide
Kerstetter et al. [76] found a statistically signiﬁcant improve-
ment in C-terminal telopeptide of type II collagen (CTX)
among older men and postmenopausal females with protein
supplementation at 163% of the RDA after a 78-week interven-
tion period. They did not observe statistically signiﬁcant effects
on serum procollagen type I N-terminal propeptide among
older men and postmenopausal women after the intervention
period [76].
Discussion
Adequate nutrition plays a vital role in the development and
maintenance of bone. In addition to calcium in the presence of
an adequate supply of vitamin D, dietary proteins represent key
nutrients for bone health and thereby function in the preven-
tion of osteoporosis. The relationship between dietary protein
intake and bone health has been a topic of debate. The scientiﬁc
literature is confounded at best. This systematic review
attempted to tease out some of the larger confounders across
clinical and prospective cohort studies.
Fractures are the most important outcome from a clinical
and health care cost savings perspective[136]. We found that
only a handful of included observational studies reported frac-
ture outcomes. The most convincing data come from an analy-
sis of the WHI, where patients who consumed 20% higher
calibrated protein intakes showed a signiﬁcant decrease in the
risk of forearm fractures. Using a doubly labeled water protocol
to estimate total energy expenditure over a 2-week period and a
urinary nitrogen protocol to estimate protein consumption
over a 24-hour period, WHI investigators showed that food fre-
quency questionnaire total energy was considerably underesti-
mated and protein was modestly underestimated, whereas the
percentage of energy from protein was overestimated. Thus,
calibration equations were developed to more accurately assess
the effect of protein intake on bone outcomes[30]. This meta-
analysis of 4 prospective studies observed a statistically signiﬁ-
cant 16% decrease in hip fractures (Figure 1) over a period of
6 years.
BMD testing is often performed every 1 to 2 years to moni-
tor and/or detect possible bone loss, predict future fracture risk,
and measure an individual ’s response to therapy. BMD is
Figure 4. Effect of protein intakes above the RDA on urinary NTX in RCTs.
JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN COLLEGE OF NUTRITION 491

currently the only universally recognized validated surrogate
endpoint of fracture [137]. Observational studies lean toward
the hypothesis that protein intake above the current RDA is
beneﬁcial to bone; however, data from clinical studies are
mixed, likely due to their shorter duration.
Our study reinforces previous studies that suggest that
higher protein intakes lead to increased urinary calcium excre-
tion. Contemporary dual stable calcium isotope studies have
found higher protein intakes to increase intestinal calcium
absorption, such that the increase in urinary calcium can be
accounted for by the improved absorption efﬁciency [14–16].
Thus, urinary calcium excretion may not play as signiﬁcant a
role in predicting associations of protein intake and bone out-
comes as previously assumed.
Bone turnover markers have the potential to assess a
response to treatment earlier than BMD testing, because BMD
changes slowly in most, but not all, metabolic bone states.
Research and development has generated many widely avail-
able bone turnover markers that measure proteins and metabo-
lites released from the bone in the breakdown phase of
resorption or the renewal phase of bone formation. Even
though there has been a recognized need to advance theﬁeld of
bone turnover markers from the International Osteoporosis
Foundation, International Federation of Clinical Chemistry
and Laboratory Medicine, and National Bone Health Alliance,
among others, these markers still lack standardization and
harmonization, and comprehensive reference population data-
bases are vital before they can be widely utilized in research
and in a clinical setting[138]. Therefore, it is not surprising
that most of the bone turnover markers in our systematic
review ﬂuctuated. These measures were likely effected by signif-
icant inter- and intralaboratory variability. The International
Osteoporosis Foundation and International Federation of Clin-
ical Chemistry and Laboratory Medicine have identiﬁed one
resorption marker (serum CTX) and one bone formation
marker (serum procollagen type I N propeptide) to be used as
reference markers and measured by standard assays in observa-
tional and intervention studies. Preanalytical sources of varia-
tion in bone turnover such as meal status, exercise, and
circadian rhythm and uncontrollable factors such as gender,
menopause status, and disease state must be accounted for
accurate comparison. For instance, peak serum CTX levels that
normally occur in the early morning hours can be twice as high
compared to those that occur in the mid-afternoon[139].I n
our study, we did notﬁnd any signiﬁcant effects of higher pro-
tein intakes on another widely measured resorption marker,
serum N-terminal telopeptide. Because theﬁeld of bone turn-
over markers is in its infancy, it is likely too premature to make
any health recommendation based upon theﬁndings of these
markers.
We found no evidence to suggest that protein intakes
above the current RDA had an adverse effect on bone. Our
systematic review did not identify any differences between
consumption of animal vs plant proteins in relation to frac-
tures and/or markers of bone health. The ﬁndings of this
systematic review are consistent with previous systematic
reviews and meta-analyses, and we further observed a signiﬁ-
cant reduction in hip fractures among included prospective
cohort studies.
Our systematic review had several strengths and limitations.
The major strength is that it eliminates a large portion of con-
founding from subjects who did not maintain energy balance
and/or were using HRT, 2 very strong drivers affecting the rate
of bone loss. HRT is known to have a protective role against
bone loss in postmenopausal women, whereas weight loss can
often contribute to decreased bone density and loss[137].T o
achieve a set of studies that reduced these confounding issues,
the review is limited by the small number of observational stud-
ies and absence of clinical studies reporting fracture outcomes.
Though many studies reported BMD outcomes, there was large
variability in the site measured. There were also a small number
of studies reporting outcomes based on animal vs plant
proteins.
sections.conclusion:
Our systematic review supports that protein intakes above the
current RDA may have some beneﬁcial role in preventing hip
fractures and BMD loss. There were no differences between
animal or plant proteins, although data in this area were scarce.
Larger, long-term, and more well-controlled clinical trials mea-
suring fracture outcomes and BMD are needed to adequately
assess whether protein intakes above the current RDA are bene-
ﬁcial as a preventative measure and/or intervention strategy for
osteoporosis.
